comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content:
Harry K. Vingut, broker and polo player, Harvard 1891.

His wife was Edith Augusta Gaynor, daughter of the New York City mayor.  The couple married in 1910, and divorced shortly before her second marriage in 1919, to Lt. James Park, Harvard 1908, heir to a steel fortune.

Here she is elsewhere in the stream, at a different event:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2422671895/]

comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: Indicator Takes Meadow Brook Cup.Stirring Race for Hunt Trophy on Harry Payne Whitney's Estate at Wheatley Hills. Harry Payne Whitney played the part of an English country squire to perfection at his country place at Wheatley Hills yesterday, the occasion being the annual meeting of the Meadow Brook Steeplechase Association. For the farmers and their families in the vicinity Mr. Whitney provided an abundant lunch, and incidentally an opportunity to get enough out of "them city fellers" to buy all the fertilizers they will need for the coming year. Source: New York Times on May 10, 1914 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10E14F7355D1373... [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5517544362/] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5516954731/] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5516954477/] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5517544362/]] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5516954587/]

comment.author: 33593953@N02
comment._content:
Richard Arthur Norton and Wystan: Thanks for providing the likely context for the photo and related photos.  We'll add the location and date to the descriptions when we update.

I particularly like some of the background details in the additional photos you pointed out (photographer with a camera; women with parasols).  It connects up with  commentary in the New York Times article that indicates that this was a place to see and be seen, with color being one missing element in the photos: "...several hundred women gay in Spring costumes and disporting resplendent parasols until the thunderstorm drove them to cover, made it all very sporty and pretty, particularly as all were enthusiastic over the racing."
